case_name: Indore Iron and Steel Registered Stock-holders Association Private Ltd. v. State of Madhya Bharat

facts.text: The appellant is the Indore Iron and Steel Registered Stock-holders Association Private Ltd., a registered association whose constituent members carry on business in fabricated iron and steel materials at Indore and Ratlam.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the Indore Iron and Steel Registered Stock-holders Association  Private  Ltd., is a registered Association whose companystituent members carry on business generally in fabricated iron and steel material and more particularly in iron sheets, plain or companyrugated, bars, rods, light and heavy structurals, nails, joints, wire nails and all kinds and varieties of wires and pipes. This business is carried on by the companystituent members of the appellant at Indore and Ratlam at which places they have their registered office.

facts.text: State of Madhya Bharat by Act No. 30 of 1950 imposed sales tax on sales of specified goods with effect from May 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Madhya Bharat, by its Act No. 30 of 1950, imposed sales tax in the territory of Madhya Bharat on the sales of goods therein specified with effect from May 1, 1950, and under the provisions of the said Act the Commissioner of Sales Tax, Madhya Bharat, and the Sales Tax Officer, Indore, who are respondents 2 and 3, were appointed authorities for the assessment of tax leviable under the Act and for its recovery in their respective areas.

facts.text: Commissioner of Sales Tax, Madhya Bharat (respondent 2) and Sales Tax Officer, Indore (respondent 3) were appointed for assessment and recovery of tax.

anchor.surface_text: and under the provisions of the said Act the Commissioner of Sales Tax, Madhya Bharat, and the Sales Tax Officer, Indore, who are respondents 2 and 3, were appointed authorities for the assessment of tax leviable under the Act and for its recovery in their respective areas. Section 3 of the Act is the charging section and it provides for the incidence of taxation, Section 4, which deals with the application of the Act, exemption and exclusion, provides by Sub-s.  2  that numbertax shall be payable under the Act on the sale of goods specified in the second companyumn of Sch. 1 on companyditions mentioned in companyumn 3 of the Schedule.

facts.text: Iron and steel appears in Sch. 1 as item 39 of the Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Iron and steel appears in Sch. 1 as item 39. Section 5 prescribes the rate of tax and it provides that the tax will be recoverable as numberified from time to time by the Government by publication in the official gazette subject to the companydition that it shall number be less than Rs. 1-9-0 per cent or more than 6 1/4 per cent.

facts.text: On May 22, 1950, a notification was issued under s. 5(2) specifying articles taxed, including item 27: goods manufactured from metals except gold and silver, etc., tax by producer or importer at Rs. 3-2-0 per cent.

anchor.surface_text: On May 22, 1950, a numberification was issued under s. 5 2  specifying serially the articles taxed, the stage of sale by traders in Madhya Bharat on which the tax is levied and the rate of sales tax per cent. Item 27 in the list dealt with goods manufactured from things  wastu  expect gold and silver or goods manufactured from more than one metal  except circles and sheets of companyper, brass and aluminium . The numberifications provided that the tax had to be paid by the producer or importer at the rate of Rs. 3-2-0 per cent.

facts.text: Article 286(3) of the Constitution came into force before the events.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile Art. 286 3  of the Constitution had companye into force. This Article as it then stood provided that numberlaw made by the Legislature of a State imposing, or authorising the imposition of, a tax on the sale or purchase of any such goods as have been declared by Parliament by law to be essential for the life of the companymunity, shall have effect unless it has been reserved for the companysideration of the President and has received his assent.

facts.text: Parliament passed Act 52 of 1952 on August 9, 1952, declaring iron and steel essential for life of community under s.2, item 14.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Parliament by law proceeded to make the declaration as companytemplated by this Article by s. 2 of Act 52 of 1952 Essential Goods  Declaration and Regulation of Tax on sale or purchase  Act  hereafter called the Act  which was passed on August 9, 1952. Section 2 of the Act provides that the goods specified in the Schedule are hereby declared to be essential for the life of the companymunity. Item 14 in the Schedule refers to iron and steel.

facts.text: On October 24, 1953, State of Madhya Bharat issued two notifications: first provides no tax on sale of iron and steel (item 39), second taxes item 9: every kind of metal excluding iron, steel, gold, silver, etc.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, as a result of these provisions iron and steel came to be declared as essential for the life of the companymunity within the meaning of Art. 286 3  as from August 9, 1952. Respondent 1 thereupon purported to give effect to the provisions of Art. 286 3  and s. 2 of the Act by issuing two numberifications on October 24, 1953. By the first numberification it was provided that numbertax shall be payable inter alia on the sale of iron and steel.Iron and steel was placed at item 39 in the said Schedule. The other numberification issued on the same day by item 9 in the list provided for the sale of the articles specified in the said item.

facts.text: It is common ground that under the October 24, 1953 notification, articles dealt by appellant's constituents are liable to sales tax.

anchor.surface_text: This item reads thus Every kind of metal including companyper, brass, manganese, zinc, lead, mercury, bronze, nickel, aluminium, tin and their ore form  excluding iron, steel, gold and silver  and goods prepared any metal other than gold and silver, utensils and wires, goods prepared from ore more than one metal, utensils and wires which also includes mangars, metal pieces and scraps, cutting and lantern, gas, stove and type-letters  excluding circles and sheets of companyper, brass and aluminium . It is companymon-ground that under this numberification the articles in which the companystituents of the appellant deal would be liable to pay the sales tax in question.

facts.text: Appellant wrote to respondent 3 claiming exemption from sales tax, plea rejected, members called to pay tax on turnover.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon-ground that under this numberification the articles in which the companystituents of the appellant deal would be liable to pay the sales tax in question. After this numberification was issued the appellant wrote to respondent 3 claiming exemption from payment of sales tax for the goods and articles in which its companystituent members are dealing but this plea was rejected by the said respondent, and the companystituent members of the appellant were called upon to pay sales tax each in respect of their individual turnover.

facts.text: Appellant filed two writ petitions under Art. 226 in High Court of Madhya Bharat at Indore: No. 26 of 1954 and 48 of 1955, challenging assessment orders for 1953-54 and 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: It was under these circumstances that the appellant filed two writ petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Madhya Bharat at Indore in which it challenged the validity of the assessment orders passed for the two years 1953-54 and 1954-55 respectively  Petitions Nos. 26 of 1954 and 48 of 1955 .

facts.text: Appellant's case in writs: articles covered by parliamentary declaration in s.2 of Act 52/1952, not liable to sales tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was that the articles in which the companystituent members of the appellant dealt were companyered by the parliamentary declaration companytained in s. 2 of the Act and as such were numberlonger liable to pay sales tax. This plea was resisted by the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents' case: notification of October 24, 1953 valid, item 27 covers articles, no writ entitled.

anchor.surface_text: This plea was resisted by the respondents. It was urged on their behalf that the numberification issued by respondent 1 on October 24, 1953 was valid, and item 27 in the list numberified brought the articles in question within the mischief of the Sales Tax Act and so the petitioners were number entitled to any writ as claimed by them.

facts.text: High Court upheld respondents' plea, rejected appellant's contentions, dismissed writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has upheld the plea raised by the respondents, rejected the companytentions urged by the appellant and has dismissed the writ petitions filed by it.

facts.text: Present appeals Nos. 509 and 510 of 1960 brought to Supreme Court by special leave against High Court dismissal orders.

anchor.surface_text: It is against these orders of dismissal passed by the High Court in the two writ petitions filed by the appellant that the present appeals, Nos. 509 and 510 of 1960, have been brought to this Court by special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: Appellant argues s.2 of Act 52/1952 covers iron and steel in commercial sense, including articles made exclusively from iron and steel.

anchor.surface_text: Two points have been urged before us by Mr. Viswanatha Sastri, on behalf of the appellant, in support of these appeals. It is urged that s. 2 of the Act which companytains the parliamentary declaration as companytemplated by Art. 286 3  companyers iron and steel as understood in their companymercial sense. The words iron and steel should number be interpreted in their narrow dictionary meaning.

facts.text: Supreme Court assumes broad interpretation of iron and steel in favour of appellant but holds impugned notification does not contravene Art. 286(3) because Act 30/1950 pre-dates parliamentary declaration.

anchor.surface_text: Since we have reached the companyclusion that even on the assumption that the parliamentary declaration made by the relevant provision of the Act includes companymodities with which we are companycerned is companyrect it does number follow that the impugned numberification companytravened Art. 286 3  we do number propose to deal with the first point raised by Mr. Sastri.

facts.text: Act 30 of 1950 was passed after Constitution but before parliamentary declaration of essential goods on August 9, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: This companydition is satisfied in the present case because the impugned numberification has been issued by virtue of the authority delegated to respondent 1 by Act 30 of 1950 and this Act was passed after the Constitution was adopted.

facts.text: Art. 286(3) requires pre-existing parliamentary declaration at time of state law for invalidity without President's assent.

anchor.surface_text: There can be little doubt that this companydition postulates that at the time when the impugned law is passed there is a preexisting declaration made by Parliament in regard to the essential character of a companymodity.

facts.text: High Court's conclusion that notification valid upheld by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: That in substance is the finding made by the High Court on the second companytention raised before it by the appellant. In our opinion, the companyclusion of the High Court on this point is right.

issues.text: whether the words 'iron and steel' in respect of which the requisite parliamentary declaration has been made by s. 2 of the Act include commodities like those with which we are concerned

anchor.surface_text: in order to succeed in the present appeals the appellant has to prove two facts, (1) that the words iron and steel in respect of which the requisite parliamentary declaration has been made by s. 2 of the Act include commodities like those with which we are concerned,

issues.text: whether the impugned notification contravenes Art. 286(3)

anchor.surface_text: and (2) that the impugned notification contravenes Art. 286 3 . It would thus be seen that unless the appellant succeeds in both these contentions the appeals are bound to fail.

issues.text: whether Art. 286(3) requires a pre-existing parliamentary declaration at the time the state law is made

anchor.surface_text: There can be little doubt that this condition postulates that at the time when the impugned law is passed there is a preexisting declaration made by Parliament in regard to the essential character of a commodity.

issues.text: whether the Madhya Bharat Sales Tax Act, 1950 is a post-Constitutional law made by the Legislature of a State imposing or authorising imposition of tax on essential goods

anchor.surface_text: The first condition is that the impugned law must be one which is made by the Legislature of a State which obviously means a State which came into existence under and after the Constitution and that shows that the impugned law must be a law made by the Legislature of a State subsequent to the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the impugned law has been reserved for the consideration of the President and received assent as required by Art. 286(3)

anchor.surface_text: Article 286 3 contemplates that if in the face of an existing parliamentary declaration about the essential character of a commodity the Legislature of a State purports to impose or authorise the imposition of a tax on such commodity the enactment would be invalid unless the law made by the Legislature has been reserved for the consideration of the President and has received his assent.

arguments.claim: s. 2 of the Act covers iron and steel as understood in their commercial sense including articles exclusively made from iron and steel

anchor.surface_text: It is urged that s. 2 of the Act which contains the parliamentary declaration as contemplated by Art. 286 3 covers iron and steel as understood in their commercial sense. The words iron and steel should number be interpreted in their narrow dictionary meaning. They do number mean iron and steel as they companye out after smelting but they mean articles exclusively made from iron and steel in which the identity of iron and steel has number been lost.

arguments.claim: Narrow dictionary meaning of iron and steel would not serve the object of Art. 286(3) to safeguard consumer interest

anchor.surface_text: In other words, iron and steel in the context mean all articles made exclusively of iron and steel in which steel merchants normally and generally trade. It is further argued that in construing the words iron and steel we must bear in mind the fact that the object of Art. 286 3 is to safeguard the interest of the consumer in regard to the articles which Parliament may declare to be essential for the life of the community,

arguments.claim: Legislative history supports broad construction of iron and steel

anchor.surface_text: and it is suggested that if the narrow dictionary meaning of the words is adopted it would not serve the said object and purpose of the constitutional provision. Mr. Sastri has also relied on what he has described as the legislative history which indicates that the said words should receive a broad and wide construction in the context. arguments.claim: Words iron and steel in Entry 14 Sch. to Act do not include articles made of iron and steel

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was not impressed by this argument. It has held that the words iron and steel as used in Entry 14 to Sch. 1 of the Act do not include within their ambit articles made of iron and steel such as those with which we are concerned in the present proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was that the articles in which the constituent members of the appellant dealt were covered by the parliamentary declaration contained in s. 2 of the Act and as such were no longer liable to pay sales tax.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ced at item 39 in the said Schedule. The other numberification issued on the same day by item 9 in the list provided for the sale of the articles spec

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court rejected; Supreme Court assumes but finds no contravention of Art. 286(3)

arguments.claim: Impugned notification does not contravene Art. 286(3) even assuming articles covered by declaration

anchor.surface_text: Since we have reached the conclusion that even on the assumption that the parliamentary declaration made by the relevant provision of the Act includes commodities with which we are concerned is correct it does not follow that the impugned notification contravened Art. 286 3 we do not propose to deal with the first point raised by Mr. Sastri.

arguments.claim: Art. 286(3) requires pre-existing parliamentary declaration when state law passed

anchor.surface_text: There can be little doubt that this condition postulates that at the time when the impugned law is passed there is a pre-existing declaration made by Parliament in regard to the essential character of a commodity. The material words in respect of this condition are that the sale or purchase of any such goods as have been declared by Parliament by law to be essential for the life of the community. Therefore, if the parliamentary declaration follows the impugned enactment it cannot retrospectively affect the validity of the said enactment.

arguments.claim: Act 30 of 1950 satisfies first condition of Art. 286(3) as post-Constitution but not second as declaration post-dates it

anchor.surface_text: The first condition is that the impugned law must be one which is made by the Legislature of a State which obviously means a State which came into existence under and after the Constitution and that shows that the impugned law must be a law made by the Legislature of a State subsequent to the Constitution. This condition is satisfied in the present case because the impugned notification has been issued by virtue of the authority delegated to respondent 1 by Act 30 of 1950 and this Act was passed after the Constitution was adopted.

arguments.claim: S.3 of Act 52/1952 applies prospectively to laws made after its commencement

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it would be relevant to refer to s. 3 of the Act itself. It provides that no law made after the commencement of this Act by Legislature of a State imposing or authorising the imposition of a tax on the sale or purchase of any goods declared by this Act to be essential for the life of the community shall have effect unless it has been reserved for the consideration of the President and has received his assent.

arguments.claim: Sardar Soma Singh v. State of Pepsu holds Art. 286(3) applies to post-constitutional laws only

anchor.surface_text: The question about the construction of Art. 286 3 has been considered by this Court on two occasions. In Sardar Soma Singh v. The State of Pepsu and Union of India (1954) S.C.R. 955, S.R. Das, J., as he then was, who spoke for the Court has observed that it is quite clear that s. 3 of Act 52 of 1952 does not affect the Ordinance there challenged for the said Ordinance was not made after the commencement of the Act,

arguments.claim: Firm of A. Gowrishankar v. Sales Tax Officer supports that Art. 286(3) contemplates post-constitutional law

anchor.surface_text: and that Art. 286 3 contemplates a law which can be but has not been reserved for the consideration of the President and has not received his assent. This position clearly points to post-constitutional law for there can be no question of an existing law continued by Art. 372 being reserved for the consideration of the President for receiving his assent. This decision supports the conclusion that the law contemplated by the first condition specified in Art. 286 3 must be post-constitutional law. To the same effect are the observations made in the majority judgment of this Court in Firm of A. Gowrishankar v. Sales Tax Officer, Secunderabad.

arguments.claim: High Court conclusion that notification valid is correct

anchor.surface_text: That in substance is the finding made by the High Court on the second contention raised before it by the appellant. In our opinion, the conclusion of the High Court on this point is right.

holdings.text: Even on the assumption that the parliamentary declaration made by the relevant provision of the Act includes commodities with which we are concerned is correct it does not follow that the impugned notification contravened Art. 286(3)

anchor.surface_text: Since we have reached the conclusion that even on the assumption that the parliamentary declaration made by the relevant provision of the Act includes commodities with which we are concerned is correct it does number follow that the impugned numberification companytravened Art. 286 3  we do number propose to deal with the first point raised by Mr. Sastri.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumes petitioner's interpretation of 'iron and steel' but holds no contravention as state Act 30/1950 predates parliamentary declaration under Act 52/1952

holdings.text: Article 286(3) postulates that at the time when the impugned law is passed there is a pre-existing declaration made by Parliament in regard to the essential character of a commodity

anchor.surface_text: There can be little doubt that this condition postulates that at the time when the impugned law is passed there is a preexisting declaration made by Parliament in regard to the essential character of a commodity. The material words in respect of this condition are that the sale or purchase of any such goods as have been declared by Parliament by law to be essential for the life of the community.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of 'any such goods as have been declared'; subsequent declaration does not retrospectively invalidate prior state law

holdings.text: The impugned law must be one which is made by the Legislature of a State subsequent to the Constitution. This condition is satisfied in the present case because the impugned notification has been issued by virtue of the authority delegated to respondent 1 by Act 30 of 1950 and this Act was passed after the Constitution was adopted

anchor.surface_text: The first condition is that the impugned law must be one which is made by the Legislature of a State which obviously means a State which came into existence under and after the Constitution and that shows that the impugned law must be a law made by the Legislature of a State subsequent to the Constitution. This condition is satisfied in the present case because the impugned notification has been issued by virtue of the authority delegated to respondent 1 by Act 30 of 1950 and this Act was passed after the Constitution was adopted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act 30/1950 is post-Constitution state legislation authorizing tax imposition

holdings.text: Act 30 of 1950 satisfies the first condition but not the second

anchor.surface_text: Thus the position is that Act 30 of 1950 satisfies the first condition but number the second. It is ceded that the relevant provisions of the M.B. Act of 1950 authorise the imposition of tax on the commodities in question and that the impugned numberification is otherwise consistent with, and justified by, the said provisions of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: First condition met (post-Constitution) but second fails (no pre-existing declaration)

anchor.surface_text: To the same effect are the observations made in the majority judgment of this Court in Firm of A. Gowrishankar v. Sales Tax Officer, Secunderabad . In this connection it would be relevant to refer to s. 3 of the Act itself. It provides that no law made after the commencement of this Act by Legislature of a State imposing or authorising the imposition of a tax on the sale or purchase of any goods declared by this Act to be essential for the life of the community shall have effect unless it has been reserved for the consideration of the President and has received his assent.

edges.explanation: reasoning on whether parliamentary declaration in Act validates notifications under impugned notification and Art. 286(3)

anchor.surface_text: Since we have reached the conclusion that even on the assumption that the parliamentary declaration made by the relevant provision of the Act includes commodities with which we are concerned is correct it does number follow that the impugned numberification companytravened Art. 286 3  we do number propose to deal with the first point raised by Mr. Sastri.

The impugned notification with which we are concerned and the Act under which it has been issued are thus outside the purview of s. 3 of the Act. That in substance is the finding made by the High Court on the second contention raised before it by the appellant. In our opinion, the conclusion of the High Court on this point is right.

There can be little doubt that this condition postulates that at the time when the impugned law is passed there is a preexisting declaration made by Parliament in regard to the essential character of a commodity. The material words in respect of this condition are that the sale or purchase of any such goods as have been declared by Parliament by law to be essential for the life of the community.

The impugned notification with which we are concerned and the Act under which it has been issued are thus outside the purview of s. 3 of the Act. That in substance is the finding made by the High Court on the second contention raised before it by the appellant. In our opinion, the conclusion of the High Court on this point is right.

The first condition is that the impugned law must be one which is made by the Legislature of a State which obviously means a State which came into existence under and after the Constitution and that shows that the impugned law must be a law made by the Legislature of a State subsequent to the Constitution. This condition is satisfied in the present case because the impugned notification has been issued by virtue of the authority delegated to respondent 1 by Act 30 of 1950 and this Act was passed after the Constitution was adopted.

The impugned notification with which we are concerned and the Act under which it has been issued are thus outside the purview of s. 3 of the Act. That in substance is the finding made by the High Court on the second contention raised before it by the appellant. In our opinion, the conclusion of the High Court on this point is right.

The impugned notification with which we are concerned and the Act under which it has been issued are thus outside the purview of s. 3 of the Act.
